titlepage.titleproper: Office of the President Mary Maples Dunn Files, 1985-1995
titlepage.subtitle: Finding Aid
titlepage.author: Compiled by Laura Finkel Sara Streett
titlepage.sponsor: Encoding funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

did.head: Collection Overview
did.unittitle: Office of the President Mary Maples Dunn Files
did.abstract: Smith College president from 1985-1995 whose administration created programs, wrote position papers, and adjusted college policies and structure in order to deal with the questions of race and sexuality. Dunn dealt with the budget during an economically troubled period and began the process of getting the college on the "Information Highway." Includes incoming and outgoing correspondence, reports and working papers, newspaper clippings and photographs.

bioghist.p: Mary Maples Dunn was Smith's president from 1985 to 1995, an economically troubled period for the college. But the imbalanced budget was just one of the challenging issues she faced during her tenure. Campus diversity, internal communication flow, and socially responsible investment were also significant issues during her presidency. However, Dunn maintained a cheerful image and a sense of humor throughout, and persevered through the trials of her difficult position.

Dunn took office in 1985 after seven years as an administrator at another of the famed Seven Sister colleges, Bryn Mawr. In fact until that point nearly the entirety of Dunn's academic career was spent at Bryn Mawr. After she received her undergraduate degree from William & Mary in 1954, she went on to Bryn Mawr to do her graduate work in colonial U.S. history. She began teaching at the college while she was completing her Ph.D. then moved through the academic and administrative hierarchy until she became Dean of the Undergraduate College in 1978 then Academic Deputy to the President in 1981.

When she arrived at Smith the first order of business was to work on her fundraising skills. Development became a significant part of the duties of the President during Jill Ker Conway's tenure. Dunn immediately set to work on enlarging the college's endowment and locating funding for several new initiatives. The battle to balance the college's books included two capital campaigns, an increase in tuition, and a number of structural changes. Alterations in employee benefit packages and offers of early retirement had a significant impact on the college staff and caused considerable distress in the community. But while scaling back in some quarters of the campus, Dunn also had to fund necessary progress. Physical changes included the construction of Bass Science Center and the Young Science Library, and a number of renovations to residence houses. She also began the process of getting the college on the "Information Highway." The internet was first introduced to campus during her tenure along with e-mail and voice mail.

As Dunn was preparing to leave the college she reflected, "It's true that acquiring budgetary accountability is among my most important achievements, but I hope I'll be remembered as a president who helped open the college up to a more diverse population." Some of Dunn's most well-known challenges were related to diversity. South African divestment was a source of much conflict on campus when she first arrived, and a few years later inadequate office space for the multicultural organizations on campus reached a fever pitch. Dunn also had to deal with continuing publicity and institutional attitudes about Smith students' sexuality. Throughout her tenure Dunn was repeatedly forced to address media coverage of Smith, Northampton and the "L-Word." Her administration created programs, wrote position papers, and adjusted college policies and structure in order to deal with the questions of race and sexuality. The most extensive program, the 1988 Smith Design for Institutional Diversity, dealt primarily with race, but other endeavors handled questions related to sexuality, physical disabilities, and derogatory language.

When Dunn left Smith 1995, she went on to become director of the Schlesinger Library on the History of Women, then interim president of Radcliffe College and acting dean of the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study. Dunn left the Radcliffe Institute to become Co-Executive Officer, with her husband Richard, of the American Philosophical Society in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. They retired from that position in July 2007.

scopecontent.p: The Dunn Files include approximately 82 linear feet (198 document boxes) of material dating from 1985-1995. Some material has been restricted according the College Archives policies. The open records (99 document boxes/ 41 linear feet) include incoming and outgoing correspondence, reports and working papers, newspaper clippings and photographs. For more specific information about the contents of the collection see the series descriptions and folder listing below. See the Subject Guide on pages 9-11 of this finding aid for a list of topics of a broad nature.

note.p: The Subject Guide is meant as a supplement to information provided in the Series Descriptions and Folder Listing, and is in no way intended as a comprehensive listing of significant subject matter in the collection.

arrangement.p: This collection is organized into eighteen series:

accessrestrict.p: Half of the collection (99 document boxes, or 41 linear feet) is open to researchers according to the regulations of the College Archives. Another 99 document boxes (41 linear feet) are currently open only to employees of the office of origin.

userestrict.p: Single photocopies may be made for research purposes. Permission to publish or quote from the documents must be obtained from the Smith College Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please use the following format when citing materials from this collection:
Office of the President Mary Maples Dunn Files, Box #, Smith College Archives.

accruals.head: Additions to the Collection
accruals.p: The Records of the Office of the President constitute a continuing collection, because certain materials remain in active use by the office for periods exceeding a president's actual tenure. The College Archives may receive accessions/additions long after the date of creation.

acqinfo.p: The majority of the Dunn Files were transferred to the College Archives from the Office of the President in a number of accessions dating from the time of her tenure until the present. Some material, however, came from Dunn herself after her departure in 1995. Additional biographical materials, such as newspaper clippings, press releases, and photographs, have been added by the College Archives staff.

processinfo.p: Processed by Laura Finkel, with the assistance of Sara Streett.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional material in the Smith College Archives about the Dunn era may be found in the records of other departments and offices of the college, as well as in the personal papers of Mary Maples Dunn.

scopecontent.p: The records in this series include newspaper clippings, press releases, and correspondence relating to Dunn's appointment, presidency and retirement. There is also information about her husband, Richard Dunn. More extensive biographical material can be found in Mary Maples Dunn's personal papers.

did.unittitle: -General Briefing Mat'l Prepared by JKC, Folder 1 June 1985
-General Briefing Mat'l Prepared by JKC, Folder 2 June 1985

arrangement.p: The files in this series are arranged alphabetically by the most recent name of the department.

scopecontent.p: Included are newspaper clippings, correspondence, and reports from the undergraduate departments of the college. Also included are programs administered by the departments. For example, files from the Smith College Campus School are included as a sub-series of the Department of Education. However, undergraduate and graduate academic programs administered either jointly by two or more departments, or by a separate and autonomous college office, are filed either with Academic Programs or Administrative Offices. Graduate Programs are filed in the Graduate Work series. Information about Five College joint academic programs in several areas of study can be found in the Intercollegiate Associations series.

p.ref: See also Series XVII. Students-Athletics
See also Series IX. Committees & Boards-Committee to Review the Athletic Dept. and the Dept. of Exercise and Sport Studies

scopecontent.p: The Academic Programs series consists of correspondence, newspaper clippings, and reports regarding academic programs administered by the college outside of the regular operations of academic departments. Those programs include the Ada Comstock Scholars Program, Junior Year Abroad, Bridge Program, Community College Connections, and several interdisciplinary programs.The Subject Guide provides references to funding sources for a number of this programs.

p.ref: See also Series VII. Buildings & Grounds-Dewey

scopecontent.p: This series documents activity in the President's Office which is either of a general nature, requiring the attention of only the president and her closest assistants, or requiring the participation of a number of administrative bodies at once. Included in this series are records relating to a number of general issues, such as Legislators and Legislation, Lesbianism, Race, and Women's Education. At the end of the series there is a collection of miscellaneous correspondence handled by the President's Office, filed in chronological order. Several issues, such as lesbianism, race and South Africa divestment, pervaded many areas of campus activity. Because material on these topics can be found under a variety of headings, a Subject Guide has been provided on pages 9-11 of this finding aid to assist the researcher.

arrangement.p: The files are arranged alphabetically by the most recent name of the office.

accessrestrict.p: Approximately 7 document boxes (3 linear feet) of Development material is open for research. Due to the sensitive nature of the development process, however, there is a large collection of material which will be closed to researchers for a minimum of seventy-five years.

scopecontent.p: The Administrative Offices series is the largest series in the Dunn Files. It includes correspondence and reports from individual offices as well as newspaper clippings and other general information about their activities and functions. There may also be useful information in the Buildings and Grounds series about the buildings in which the various offices were housed. Development comprises the largest section of the Administrative Offices series.

accessrestrict.p: Note: Boxes 2-5 of the Alumnae series is restricted until June 2005, because of its alphabetical rather than chronological arrangement.

scopecontent.p: This series includes material on a number of issues related to the alumnae, as well as the Alumnae Association and its activities. The bulk of the files contain information about the Alumnae Association, class reunions, Smith Clubs, and specific individuals. The section related to individuals is in alphabetical order, and contains correspondence to, from and about alumnae. Many are routine and pro forma letters of thank you for attending certain functions, or congratulations on administrative successes. However, there are also letters scattered throughout addressing specific issues pertinent to the period. Information about alumnae involvement with Admissions can be found in the records of Alumnae/Admissions Task Force in the Committees and Boards series, and in the records of the Admissions Office's Candidates Committees in the Administrative Offices series.

p.ref: See Series IX. Committees & Boards-College/Alumnae Task Force on Diversity
See Series IX. Committees & Boards-Strategic Planning Committees-Dining

arrangement.p: Student residences are grouped together and organized alphabetically.

scopecontent.p: This series includes records related to the maintenance and development of campus structures and infrastructure. The largest construction projects during Dunn's term was the renovation of the Clark Science Center.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the Committees and Boards series in the records of the Campus Planning Committee, Facilities Planning Committee, Committee on Faculty Offices, Grounds Committee, Ad-hoc Committee for the Selection of Architects and Supervision of Building Programs, Committee on Space Allocation, and the Campus Beautification Committee. There is additional information in the Administrative Offices series in the records of the Physical Plant as well as the Assistant to the President for Campus Planning (President's Office).

arrangement.p: The files are organized alphabetically by institution, with a series of alphabetical miscellaneous material at the end.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, reports and newspaper clippings from other institutions regarding cooperative programs, institutional activities and events, as well as common educational issues.

relatedmaterial.p: For institutions of either the Five Colleges, Seven Sisters or Twelve College Exchange, see also the Intercollegiate Associations series.

did.unittitle: -International Conference on Worldwide Education for Women 1987

scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence, reports and working papers of the standing and ad-hoc committees and boards of the college. The most central and far-reaching decision-making bodies are the Board of Trustees, the Board of Counselors, and the Committee on Planning and Resources (previously the College Planning Committee and the Faculty Planning Committee). However, college policy and the Family Education Rights and Privacy Act require the restriction of the records of both the Board of Trustees and the Board of Counselors. Other significant committees in this series include several faculty committees, the Committee on Social Responsibility and the Committee on Student Affairs. Also included in this series are three free-standing administrative groups: Administrative Department Heads, Senior Administrative Group, and Senior Staff. The files of the Senior Staff are the most extensive of these three groups. The Senior Staff (also know as the President's Staff) included key administrative figures, such as the Treasurer, the Directors of Development and Public Relations, Assistants to the President, and Deans and Associate Deans. Minutes and major reports from most committees are available in the Dean of the Faculty Records of the Smith College Archives.

scopecontent.p: This series of records works in concert with the Speeches and Events series to provide a detailed description of the activities and responsibilities of the President of Smith College. Included are a set of files containing details of various off-campus appointments and events the president attended (organized by date of event or appointment). There are also a set of calendars, daily schedules, travel schedules, and a sample of engagements the president had to refuse. Note: Frances Volkman was acting president for the spring semester of 1991.

did.unittitle: February 1993-National Association of Principals of Schools for Girls 1992

scopecontent.p: Along with the Speeches and Engagements series, the records in this series document the activities and responsibilities of the President of Smith College. The events in this series (as opposed to the Engagements series) include significant campus traditional gatherings and celebrations as well as one-time happenings. Routine events include assemblies, commencement, Rally Day, and the awarding of Smith College Medals and honorary degrees. Other events include Dunn's inauguration, concerts, conferences, symposia, lectures, as well as various events at the President's House.

did.unittitle: -About Women: Teaching and Research at Smith 1992-1993

scopecontent.p: The records in this series document the relationship of the President's Office with faculty and staff. There is information on a number of general faculty and staff issues, such as salaries and retirement, as well as information about specific individuals. Material relating to emeritus faculty and staff (including former Smith presidents and their families) can be found in this series as well.

relatedmaterial.p: Additional material for specific faculty or staff members may be found in the Academic Departments, Administrative Offices, or Committees and Boards series. The Committees and Boards series also includes records for a number of faculty and staff-related committees. The records of the Women and Social Change Project, a faculty-research endeavor, is also included in this series.

did.unittitle: Equal Opportunity Policy and Grievance Procedures

p.ref: See Series XVI. Students-Athletics-Basketball
See Series V. Admin. Offices-Development-Fdns-Mellon Fdn (1992 and 1993).

See also Series V. Administrative Offices-Development-Foundations-Ford Foundation

scopecontent.p: The Graduate Work series includes correspondence, newspaper clippings, and reports regarding the evolution and operation of several graduate studies programs at the college. There are records documenting general aspects of graduate education, as well as specific programs of study, such as the the Smith-Northampton Summer School, the Smith Management Program, and the School of Social Work.

relatedmaterial.p: Useful information may also be found in the Committees and Boards series on the Committee on Graduate Study.

p.ref: See also Series V. Administrative Offices-Development-Corporations-Citicorp

scopecontent.p: There are four intercollegiate associations included in this series: Five Colleges, Inc., Seven Sisters, Society Organized Against Racism, and Women's College Coalition.

Five Colleges: The Five Colleges material includes correspondence, reports and newspaper clippings tracing the evolution of cooperative relations between Smith College, Mount Holyoke College, Hampshire College, Amherst College, and the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.

Seven Sisters: The records of the Seven Sisters (also known as the Seven Colleges) include correspondence, reports and newspaper clippings documenting relations between seven of the most important historically women-only colleges in the Eastern United States: Barnard, Bryn Mawr, Mount Holyoke, Radcliffe, Smith, Vassar, and Wellesley.

Society Organized Against Racism (SOAR): The SOAR records include correspondence and reports documenting the founding and early activity of the organization. SOAR, founded in 1982, is a consortium of New England colleges and universities working to improve the racial climate in academic institutions.

Women's College Coalition: The Women's College Coalition was founded in 1972 under the auspices of the Association of American Colleges. It includes more than seventy two- and four-year colleges. The material in this collection includes correspondence, reports and announcements of the organization's events and projects.

arrangement.p: The files in this series are organized alphabetically by organization name, with a number of miscellaneous organizations also filed alphabetically, in the last few boxes.

scopecontent.p: The material in this series documents the variety of national, regional and local organizations which had an impact on, and a relationship with, Smith College. Included are reports, newspaper clippings and correspondence with a number of academic, civic, corporate and nonprofit organizations. Organizations of particular interest are the Association of Independent Colleges and Universities in Massachusetts (AICUM), the Consortium on Financing Higher Education (COFHE), and state and federal government bodies.

arrangement.p: The records in this series are filed chronologically by event and are labeled with one or all of the following: title, location, and event.

scopecontent.p: The duties of the President included many public speaking engagements, not only at Smith College events but also at local and national gatherings. The records in this series include notes and some full texts for many of these speeches, as well as associated correspondence and newspaper clippings.

relatedmaterial.p: More detailed information about the events themselves can be found in the Events and Engagements series, and in some cases in the records of sponsoring Smith Administrative Offices, Academic Departments, Committees and Boards, or Non-Smith Organizations.

scopecontent.p: The records in this series document the relationship of the Smith student body with the faculty and administration of the college. There are records about student organizations, publications, athletics, and other activities.

relatedmaterial.p: Information about students can also be found in the records of Committees and Boards with student representation, in the Administrative Offices series in the records of the Dean of the College and the Dean of Students, as well as in the records of specific student residences in the Buildings and Grounds series.

p.ref: See also Series IX. Committees & Boards-Committee to Review the Athletic Department and the Department of Exercise and Sport Studies

scopecontent.p: The photographs in this series document many of the events and activities described in the printed material.

relatedmaterial.p: Additional photographs may be found in the Smith College Archives collections which document specific events, such as Honorary Degree presentations, Ivy Day and Commencement.
